solution.text:
Step One
  • Flip equation A and divide it by a factor of 2, because we want \(NH_3\) as a reactant.
  • Flip equation B, because we need \(CH_4\) as a reactant.
  • Divide equation C by a factor of 2, because we want \(HCN\) as a product.
Step Two - Revised Equations
  • \(NH_3(g) \rightarrow \frac{1}{2} N_2(g) + \frac{3}{2}H_2(g) \qquad \Delta H =_{{j*0.5}}_ \frac{kJ}{mol}\)
  • \(CH_4(g) \rightarrow C(s) + 2H_2(g) \qquad \Delta H = _{k}_ \frac{kJ}{mol}\)
  • \(\frac{1}{2} H_2(g) + C(s) + \frac{1}{2} N_2(g) \rightarrow HCN(g) \qquad \Delta H = _{{l*0.5}}_ \frac{kJ}{mol}\)
Step Three : Add the revised equations to get the desired one
\(NH_3(g) + CH_4(g) + \frac{1}{2} H_2(g) + C(s) + \frac{1}{2} N_2(g) \rightarrow \frac{1}{2} N_2(g) + \frac{3}{2}H_2(g) + C(s) + 2H_2(g) + HCN(g)\)
\(\implies CH_4(g) + NH_3(g) \rightarrow HCN(g) + 3H_2(g)\)

Step Four : Add the revised enthalpies
\(\implies \Delta H = _{{j*0.5}}_ + _{k}_ + _{{l*0.5}}_ = _{{j*0.5+k+(0.5*l)}}_\frac{kJ}{mol}\)

content.text:
Calculate the enthalpy of change for the reaction below that is conducted at a certain temperature and pressure:
\(CH_4(g) + NH_3(g) \rightarrow HCN(g) + 3H_2(g)\)

Given that the following reactions are conducted under the same conditions:\(N_2(g) + 3H_2(g) \rightarrow 2NH_3(g) \qquad \Delta H = -_{j}_ \frac{kJ}{mol} \qquad (A)\)
\(C(s) + 2H_2(g) \rightarrow CH_4(g) \qquad \Delta H = -_{k}_ \frac{kJ}{mol} \qquad (B)\)
\(H_2(g) + 2C(s) + N_2(g) \rightarrow 2HCN(g) \qquad \Delta H = _{l}_ \frac{kJ}{mol} \qquad (C)\)
